newsitem.title: UK: Gold OTC vols spike higher as bullion slides.
newsitem.headline: Gold OTC vols spike higher as bullion slides.

text.p: Business in over-the-counter gold options was brisk and volatilities soared to levels not seen for nearly a year as the underlying price plummeted, dealers said.

One month implied volatilities zoomed up to as high as 11.5 percent this week as bullion prices dropped to fresh 3-1/4 year lows, they said. January had eased slightly on Thursday morning to around 10.0/11.0 percent.
"It obviously warrants these volatilities in the short term. It's vicious. And some of the buying has filtered into the longer term as well," an options dealer said.
A week ago high bids were at around 10 percent, versus 6.1 percent at the end of last year, following a steep decline in the underlying price so far this year.
Since Tuesday the gold price has been subject to dramatic gyrations, swinging from highs around $360 to a low of $351.40 amid an overall downtrend.
"The vols are not as high as when gold got up to $415 (in February 1996), when one-month got up to 15 percent. So there's room for them to go higher," a dealer said.
A concentration of open interest was seen at or around $350 an ounce, the psychologically significant support level for spot gold, dealers said.
"There's a long-term support line at around $350-$351. People seem to have bought in advance of that," he said.
But interest in the $345 area, seen by some analysts as the next downside target, and even lower was also cropping up.
"Today for the first time I sold a $330 strike. The $340s have been in play a few times but otherwise they have been concentrated between $350 and $370," a dealer in continental Europe said.
Both puts and calls were in demand, and the market was mixed as to the short term future of the gold price, dealers said.
However, puts appeared to be taking precedence, reflecting an overall bearish tone.
"The market is a bit crazy now, there is a lot of volatility. People are afraid of the downside basically," one European dealer said.
"The puts have been coming in on the short end, and on the long end, the one-year stuff, there's been some producer selling of calls around $370 and $380," another dealer said.
"The professional market is not as busy as I would have expected. It's more lively, but not in big amounts, in 10-20,000 ounces," he added.
Longer term volatilities were slightly firmer.
On Thursday morning, three month implied volatilities were bid at 9.0 percent, six months at 8.0 to 8.75 percent and 12-month at 7.7 percent.
"When the market is excited like this it starts in the short term. For now the one year volatility is up just a bit," the dealer said.
